titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to Archives of Irish America Pamphlet Collection AIA.047
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rebecca Altermatt

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-03-28T16:07-0400

did.unittitle: Archives of Irish America Pamphlet Collection
did.abstract: This collection consists of pamphlets on topics related to Irish political, social and cultural issues. The collection contains several pamphlets relating to the history of political tensions between Ireland and Great Britain and includes original pamphlets written by James Connolley, Socialist and organizer for the Irish Transport and General Workers Union, and Eamon de Valera, President of Ireland.
did.langmaterial: Materials are in English and Irish.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

list.item: Archives of Irish America Vertical Files Collection AIA 013

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Pamphlets are organized alphabetically by title. Pamphlets are arranged into two series.

list.item: Series II. Ernie O'Malley Pamphlet Collection, 1903-1924

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; Archives of Irish America, Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Archives of Irish America, Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: irisharchives@library.nyu.edu

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The Archives of Irish America, a special collection of the Tamiment Library documenting the history of Irish in America, accumulated this artificial collection of printed ephemera gradually over the years through purchases, donations, and active collection by staff. Some of the pamphlets were removed from manuscript collections and put into this collection to facilitate access.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Archives of Irish America, a special collection of the Tamiment Library documenting the history of Irish in America, accumulated this artificial collection of printed ephemera gradually over the years through purchases, donations, and active collection by staff. Collection of pamphlets is ongoing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Archives of Irish American Pamphlet Collection consists of pamphlets collected from a variety of sources including staff, vertical files and the Cormac K. H. O'Malley collection which contained pamphlets from O'Malley's father, Ernie O'Malley, and IRA officer active during the 1919-1921 Irish War of Independence and later an author himself. (See related collection Ernie O'Malley Papers, AIA 060.)

The pamphlets date from as early as 1843 and comment on social and political activities in Northern Ireland. Authors represented include Eamon de Valera, James Connelly, Francis Sheey Skeffington, Sean O'Casey, Gerald O'Reilly and Bobby Sands. Pamphlets in Series I: General Collection document 19th and 20th century issues in the United States and abroad including immigration, treatment of prisoners in Ireland and deportation cases, socialism, as well as other issues related to Irish Republicanism. The Ernie O'Malley pamphlets in Series II include pamphlets from the early 1900s, some rare describing on Irish political conditions and activities. Also of note is An Smaointeori, which is signed by Liam Mellows to Ernie O'Malley.

unittitle.emph: Undisguised Anglo-American Alliance. Celebration of "One Hundred Years of Peace" with England. A skillfully [sic] planned and dangerous attempt to link the two nations together - France and Germany, who helped to make this country free, to be invited only to participate in English festivities, and Russia, whose action foiled England's Plan to break up the Union, wholly ignored-scheme to Anglicize the schools-Wharton Barker's Emphatic Protest.
